      • goToStartScreen

        public void goToStartScreen()
        goToStartScreen is called in 'start' method and loads the application's start-up screen

        User can choose to create a new shopping list, open an existing one, or import an externally created list.

        Date Modified: 6 Mar 2014

      • goToCreateNewListScreen

        public void goToCreateNewListScreen()
        goToCreateNewListScreen is called when the user chooses to create a new shopping list on the start screen. It loads a screen which allows the user to enter the name for the new list.

        User creates new list

        Date Modified: 3 May 2014

      • goToAllShoppingListsScreen

        public void goToAllShoppingListsScreen()
        goToAllShoppingListsScreen is called when the user chooses to open a previously created shopping list on the start screen. It loads the screen to show the user previously created lists.

        User can view previously created shopping lists

        Date Modified: 6 Mar 2014

      • goToHomeScreen

        public void goToHomeScreen()
        goToHomeScreen is called when the 'Home' button is pressed. It loads the screen which allows the user to browse through different product categories, or alternatively search for a product directly.

        User navigates through product database

        Date Modified: 28 Feb 2014

        Parameters:
        enteredListName -

      • goToFavourites

        public void goToFavourites()
        goToFavourites is called when the 'Favourites' button is pressed. It loads the screen which allows the user to browse through his favourite products.

        User can maintain list of favourite products

        Date Modified: 28 Feb 2014

      • goToShoppingList

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        The main() method is ignored in correctly deployed JavaFX applications. main() serves only as fallback in case the application cannot be launched through deployment artifacts, e.g., in IDEs with limited FX support.
        Parameters:
        args - the command line arguments

        Date Modified: 22 Feb 2014
